Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Mini-Access Versus Sternotomy in Total Arch Replacement

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either mini-access TAR (n=40) or sternotomy TAR (n=55).

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at Asan Medical Center, Seoul, Korea, enrolling 95 patients undergoing elective TAR

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to either mini-access TAR (n=40) or sternotomy TAR (n=55).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy and safety of mini-access total arch replacement (TAR) compared to conventional sternotomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was a composite of early mortality and disabling stroke within 30 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the nature of the interventions.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomised to either mini-access TAR (n=40) or sternotomy TAR (n=55).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Participants were randomised to either mini-access TAR (n=40) or sternotomy TAR (n=55).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mini-access group showed a lower risk of the primary composite outcome (odds ratio, 0.88; 95% CI, 0.78-1.00; P=0.049)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were less frequent in the mini-access group.
